sp.speaker: For:
sp.l: Diſpatch then and tell vs what it is.

sp.speaker: Se:
sp.l: Let none but I be executioner to cut off Lelios head.

sp.speaker: Duke:
sp.l: We grant thy ſute.

sp.speaker: Sem:
sp.l: Then giue me this keene ſword
Since none but Experience
Hath power to cut off vertues noble head,
Thou ſhalt not die.

sp.speaker: For:
sp.l: Do not delude our truſt.

sp.speaker: Sem:
sp.l: Nor do you condemne a guiltles man.
O Charitie is come, I ſee him now.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.l: Heads-man diſpatch, except Sempronio liue, Lelio muſt die.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.l: Sempronio liues, my Lord, ſee where he ſtands.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.l: Hermit why dallieſt thou?
Sempronio was yong, but this is olde,
Sempronio was dead, but he doth liue:

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: Old Sempronio now is young againe,
And dead Sempronio now doth liue,
Beholde him Lelio, doſt thou know him now?

sp.speaker: Lel:
sp.l: Sempronio.

sp.speaker: Sem:
sp.l: Ah deare Lelio.

sp.speaker: Her:
sp.l: This Lord left dead by ſhepheards in the field,
Was found againe, and healed thus by me,
And by my art hauing his haire diſguiſde,
He paſt a ſolemne oath to hide his name,
And doo good deeds where he had liued looſe,
Since when, cald Penitent Experience,
He hath remaind, and liu'd a penſiue life.
Speake my Sempronio, for I diſcharge thy vow,
Tell thou the reſt, for why my viſion
Foretolde and promiſt ſuch an accident,
As neuer Venice had, or ſawe the like.

sp.speaker: Sem:
sp.l: Sempronio liues, and Lelio now muſt liue,
Greeu'd for my breach of faith, greeu'd for my crime,
Heere are the tokens of my fatall wounds,
Which when I eyed Annetta, I haue wept,
To thinke vpon my looſe vnbrideled loue.
Let vs not ioy in words, but ioy in hearts,
And let our armes our tongues diſcourſe imbrace,
Where our three liues are heard of agen,
Call them three knackes to finde out honeſt men.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.l: God wrought theſe things, we do applaud his works
See how by mute imbrace theſe friends imbrace,
Marke how they whiſper in each others eares,
Their troublous fortunes, cares, & diſcontents,
And now loue workes, ſee how Lelio hand in hand
Ioynes Sempronio with his Lucida,
The holy hermit knitteth vp the knot,
And all applaud this vnitie of peace.
How now? what ſeekes this maide?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pardon for my father.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.l: Comſt thou to plead for Seruio Phillida?
Go fetch him forth, ioy ſhall haue fulnes now:
Sempronio ſtand aſide, wele make ſome ſport.

stage.hi: Enter Phillida with her father Seruio.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Now Seruio, for thy forfeit to the ſtate,
What fine wilt thou affoord for libertie.

sp.speaker: Ser:
sp.l: Dread Lord, thoſe lands and profits fell to me,
By deare Sempronios death, my neere a kin,
I frankly giue in lieu of my contempt.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.l: What wilt thou make bequeath of others lands:
Why man he liues againe.

sp.speaker: Ser:
sp.l: Firſt tell me I am dead my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.l: Thou muſt reſtore to him his goods againe.
O miſery, Is he reſtord to life, to take away my goods
Command me death, nay priſonment, and what ye wil,
So he reuiue not, ſo I meet him not.

sp.speaker: Sem:
sp.l: See here the picture of true auarice,
Where men preferre their goods before their friends,
How fare you vnkle?

sp.speaker: Ser:
sp.l: Ieſus bleſſe me, a ſpirit. What coſin?

sp.speaker: Sem:
sp.l: I vnkle, the ſame, and grieue not to yeeld your kinſman his right.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.l: Nay force perforce he ſhall reſtore thy owne.
Phillida behold, thy vnkle liues:
See my Lords, no care of kindred holdeth her,
She runs to meet Orphinio, loue conducteth her.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.l: Are you returnd my Lord, what ſafe returnd?

sp.speaker: Orp:
sp.l: Returnd to keepe my faith with Phillida.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.l: Knit vp that knot within with iollitie,
And Regiſter record this commoditie.

sp.speaker: Sem:
sp.l: Nay ſtay my Lord, before this comicke end,
Let, meaſure knackes to finde out honeſt men,
For all theſe liſtning eares would finde them out.
Who liſt to know a perfect honeſt man,
Shall ſee his purſe ſtill open to the poore,
His tongue deteſting lewd detractions,
He ſcornes to grieue the needfull heart with griefe,
But liues as borne to euerie mans releefe:
A knaue will gaine by all vnlawfull meanes,
But good men ſtill their goods by vertue gleanes.
A knaue makes ſhift his thrift, forſweares and lies,
An honeſt man on loue and faith relyes:
A knaue makes luſt his loue, reſpects no friend,
An honeſt man for friendſhip life will ſpend.
Oh how I ſhould tire both tong, thought, and pen,
To ſcan out knaues from perfect honeſt men:
Point where I liſt, if ſo my finger light
On honeſtie, I ſweare I point aright.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.l: Thankes good Sempronio for this worthie skill,
To regiſter the memorie of this,
Henceforth where ere this hiſtorie is heard,
The worlde ſhall praiſe thee, in whoſe life began,
The perfect knacke to knowe an honeſt man.
